div1.p: Tate responds to a series of questions from Hench concerning his recollections about Camp Columbia and the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Interview with Paul L. Tate by Philip Showalter Hench, June 21, 1954
div1.p:
Interview - Dr. Philip S. Hench with Mr. Paul L. Tate,
June 21, 1954, in San Francisco, California.

(The questions by Dr. Hench are numbered, but there are
sub-questions which are not numbered)

list.item:
1. What is your name and address?
a. Paul Lambert Tate, 1530 Tyler Street, Berkeley.

2. Where were you born, and when?
a. May 4, 1871 in Washington, D. C.

3. What was your occupation before you went to war? You were
a reporter, weren't you?
a. I was a reporter on the WASHINGTON STAR -- for five
years.

What else did you do before you went in the Army?
a. Well before I went to work on the STAR I worked a
short time in the Railway and Mail Service. I was working
on the STAR when the war broke out.

4. a You enlisted in what outfit?
a. I enlisted first in the 3rd Virginia Volunteers --
an infantry outfit.

When did you enlist? And where?
a. June 6, 1898.

In Washington?
a. No. Fredericksburg, Virginia. I had to go down there.
You see I belonged to the District of Columbia National Guard
and they got away before I could get back in them. So in Virginia
1.
-- the old 3rd Virginia was a famous regiment and I thought
sure they'd be sent to the front, so I went down to Fredericks-
burg and enlisted in that--the 3rd Virginai Infantry
(Mr. Tate added the following in concise form: Enlisted
3rd Va. Infty. June 6, 1898; discharged Nov. 6, 1898;
Enlisted Hospital Corps Nov. 21, 1898; discharged
at Ft. Bayard, N Mex. Nov 28, 1904--2 terms,
6 years, 5 months continuous service.)

4 b Where did you have your training?
a. At Camp Alger, Virginia.

5. 5 When did you go over to Cuba?
a. I got there -- to Havanna, Dec. 9, 1898 and we went to
Pinar del Rio the same night on the train.

What did you do then?
a. Well, we set up camp that night on arrival.

You were in the Infantry then?
a. No, no, I was in the Hospital Corps I didn't go with the
3rd Virginia Infantry. I got discharged from that Nov. 6, 1898
because they didn't go to the front. I was discharged in
Richmond, Virginia. The war wasn't really over yet, so I heard
they had an ambulance corps at Augusta, Georgia and I went down
there and enlisted in the ambulance corps. It turned out to
be a hospital corps.

When was that?
a. That was Nov. 30, 1898.

You went over with the hospital corps?
a. Yes.

What outfit? Did they call it the Hospital Corps?
a. Well, it was commanded by a volunteer, Major De Neidman.
2.

Was it just a Hospital Corps?
a. No, ... there were some troops over there, but I don't
remember who they were. They were a miscellaneous outfit.

How many in your outfit?
a. Well, it was a pretty big outfit. I think there was
about 53, all told.

All enlisted men?
a. No. There was about 53 enlisted men and they had at that
time five doctors and five full stewards and four acting
stewards.

Who were the doctors -- remember?
a. Dr. Lovejoy was one. I was trying to think of the major's
name that commanded it, but I can't think of it.
(Mr. Tate has added the following memorandum: I now have the
names of some of the doctors at Hospital at Pinar del Rio.
Most of these were with us when we encamped there, but most of
of them were detached before the arrival of Capt. Godfrey, so
it won't be of much benefit to you, but I list them:
Major De Neidman (of Volunteers) C.O.
Major Williams
Lt. Donaldson
Lt. Newlove
Lt. Personol*
Lt. Cooke (came later)
Lt. Amador
Capt. Godfrey
(None of these were Reg. Army except Godfrey)
The Stewards were:
Dextor, Lawrence, Lind, (Head, Non-Com.) Minor & Johnson.
Acting Stewards: Smithson, McVeigh, Arnold Fitzgerald.
(continuing from the interview)

Any officer who was later connected with yellow fever -- ?
a. No. They were just temporary -- a lot of volunteers there
and they all left later on.

6.#6 Now, you're at Pinar del Rio -- you arrived there when?
*different spelling, later
3.
a. Sept. 9th. -- No, not Sept. 9th, arrived Dec. 9th.

What did you do there -- you were a clerk in the Hospital Corps?
a. Yes. But I wasn't a clerk then. I was just an ordinary
man in the Hospital Corps. I never did any nursing, or
anything like that. I had no special duties, there are lots
of things to be done around a camp. I remember once I worked
in the Cook House, not as a cook, just a helper. I wasn't a
nurse, so I never had anything to do with that.

You lived in tents?
a. Yes, in tents.
(identification of a photograph of the
tent hospital)

When did you become a clerk with Capt. Godfrey?
a. I can't remember but after that we built a hospital,
a big hospital, and Capt. Godfrey came there and took command
of us. It seems to me that was the latter part of 1899 -- I
think it was sometime in the fall.

7. #7 How many soldiers, roughly, were there ?in Pinar del Rio?
a. I don't know. There were a lot of them. I don't know
whether it was all of the 1st Infantry. There must have been
about 1000. 700 of the 1st Infantry. We had to chase bandits
over the mountains so they brought Mountain Batteries and pack
mules from the United States. Most of the time there were
between two and three thousand soldiers.

Were they in tents always?
a. All tents.

What was the size of the town? (Pinar del Rio)
a. I'd say -- I'd guess between five and ten thousand.
4.
(Note: Dr. Hench was told in Pinar by a man who lived there,
that there were about 12,000 in 1900)

I am interested now in the epidemic. Can you tell me when you
first saw Dr. Cooke?
a. Dr. Cooke was a doctor in the 1st Inf. -- he wasn't
connected with the hospital.

When did he come?
a. I don't know -- I can't remember. I know he was with
the 1st Inf. and then he came over and was attached to the
hospital and then the next time I saw him, he was in
Columbia Barracks.

So you don't remember anything about Dr. Cooke? In Pinar del Rio?
a. No.

8. #8 Tell us about the epidemic of yellow fever that began in the
spring of 1900. According to my notes Dr. Gen. Truby P 94 ✓
said it began about April 20th and was still going the middle
of July. July 16, 1900
a. There was a peculiar situation. All of a sudden there
were a lot of extra deaths. They weren't diagnosed yellow
fever. A lot of us knew it was yellow fever ......

Now, wait a minute, why do you say you knew it was yellow fever?
a. Because we were in town so much and there they made
no secret of it. When they had a case of yellow fever,
some new Spaniard had moved in there and had yellow fever.

Did you speak Spanish?
a. I knew enough to get along.
5.

So, in town you heard of yellow fever -- it's called ‘vomito negro’?
a. I was around town and in the bars, and I knew enough
Spanish to understand people and I heard them speaking about
people in town, Spanish immigrants, who had vomito negro;
and so I knew there was yellow fever in town.

Do you remember when it was?
a. That's too long ago -- I don't remember -- sometime in
the summer, I imagine.

Then you say, suddenly a lot of soldiers began to get sick, and
they came to the hospital, and it was called malaria?
a. They called it ‘pernicious’ malaria.

But you knew, and you think many of the enlisted men were certain
it was yellow fever?
a. Yes.

Were you upset by it?
a. No. Well, some of them were, because fellows who were
new down there were awful scared of yellow fever. I know
I was when I first went there, but after a while I got
used to it, and didn't bother any more about it. The
reason I know it was in town was this: When we found out
it was yellow fever, they put a quarentine on between the
town and the camp. I heard fellows talking in the hospital,
saying what's the use of a quarantine -- we've got yellow
fever, they've got yellow fever in Pinar del Rio ----
6.

In other words, the quarantine was to protect the camp, not the
city -- the quarantine meant that the soldiers could not go
to the town because of the yellow fever?
a. Yes.

Now, do you remember when it was that they found there was
yellow fever there? Was that after Dr. Agramonte came, or
before?
a. We knew before....a lot of men......

When did they quarantine --- when was the quarantine put on?
After Agramonte came?
a. After Agramonte came.

The point is this --- after Agramonte came there, finally the
doctors learned that it was yellow fever. And then there was
a quarantine put on against the town?
a. Yes, Sir.

To keep the soldiers from going down town to Pinar del Rio? But
the soldiers laughed about this because they knew there was as
much yellow fever in the camp as there was down town -- right?
a. There wasn't so much down town because the Cubans
didn't get it -- when the Spaniards came in, they got it.

Now, even before that, the soldiers in the hospital .....
a. Knew all about it. They were sure it was yellow fever.

Did you discuss that with the doctors -- did you ask the doctors
whether this was yellow fever?
7.
a. No, -- oh, no, we wouldn't ask the doctors that.

You wouldn't have had the nerve to do that?
a. No.

And you attended many post mortems, did you?
a. Oh, yes.

Was that before Agramonte came?
a. Before Agramonte came.

And they were done by Capt. Godfrey?
a. Yes.

Now, about these post mortems -- did you know it was yellow
fever?
a. I didn't know anything about it then.

When you knew there was yellow fever there, by that time you
weren't scared by it? Why was that?
a. Oh, I don't know. There's so much of it, you just
get used to it. There's so much disease there in Pinar
del Rio, as long as you stay well for a long time you male?
never bothered anything about it. None of the nurses female?
ever got it.

Was there any panic among the troops?
a. I don't know -- I couldn't tell you that

Was there any panic among the Cubans themselves?
a. No.
8.

Was there any panic among the hospital corps personnel?
a. I don't remember. I don't think so.

Was there any concern -- were they worried?
a. No -- I don't think so. I'll give you one illustration
as to why I don't think so. Shortly before they had yellow
fever, they wanted to get three volunteers to go to Guanajay
where they had a lot of yellow fever. The first sergeant
came out and had us in line and he said they had yellow
fever at Guanajay and he said he would never send a nurse
there unless there were volunteers to nurse yellow fever.
They wanted three nurses to volunteer. He turned his eyes
left for a second, and while he did so, every man in the
outfit stepped forward and he was one of those tough guys,
and he looked around and said, “Well, you all want to be
heroes, eh! Darned good thing, because I wouldn't trust
some of you to nurse a cat, now I can pick three good
nurses” .... I stepped forward too, and I had no idea of
nursing yellow fever, but I knew they wouldn't take me
anyhow.

You don't remember who they chose?
a. No.

9. #9 Now, Dr. Agramonte--he came on July 19th--tell us about that.
a. I remember him because he went through the ward with
Capt. Godfrey and I went along with them to take any
notes Capt. Godfrey wanted to make. It's the only ...
it was the first time I had seen Agramonte. And I
9.
noticed the funny way he looked at some of those patients.
He knew they had yellow fever, and then he would glance
at Capt. Godfrey and he had such a funny quizzical look
on his face -- wondering how he could miss that -- how
he could call it anything but yellow fever -- that was
the impression I got.

Capt. Godfrey was still calling it malaria -- and you knew that
it was yellow fever ---
a. Well, I wasn't certain. I had a good idea that a lot
of it was yellow fever. I wouldn't know that all of it was.
Now, did all of the personnel in the hospital have the same
notion? Did they think it was possibly yellow fever?
a. I couldn't tell you that.

But you did?
a. I knew it, and a lot of others did. You know you
associate with a certain number and you know what they
think, but there are others that you are not around and
you don't know what they think.

But you suspected some of it was yellow fever, and so you knew
what Capt. Agramonte meant by the funny look on his face?
a. Yes, sure I could see that he was surprised that
Capt. Godfrey didn't see that it was yellow fever.

Do you know anything about conversation between Agramonte and Godfrey?
a. No. I remember nothing they said.
10.
Identification of photographs:
Can you locate on the map where the hospital was? --- Mr. Tate
says that the tent hospital was rather far behind, over half a
mile behind and to the left of the cuartel. The wooden hospital
was nearer the cuartel and on the right of the tent hospital.
---------
Discussion of John Morris. Mr. Tate thinks he lives (if still
alive) at 230-1/2 Cedar Street, Reading, Pa. He (Morris) enlisted
in the Hospital Corps. He worked down at Camp Lazear. Mr. Tate
thought that would show in the general orders which he handled.
-----------

Now, can you tell us anything more about Dr. Agramonte?
a. No, nothing more about Agramonte.

Was there any comment among the soldiers or the doctors about
what he told them, that it was yellow fever?
a. I don't remember.

How soon did Capt. Godfrey give indication that he knew now that
it was yellow fever -- right away -- the next day?
a. Right away. He put on a quarantine.

When?
a. Right after Agramonte left -- the next day.

That's when they put a quarantine against the whole camp?
a. Yes. We had a quarantine on the hospital that we weren't
to go to town or go out of there anywhere. So, of course, he
knew it was yellow fever then.

The whole camp was quarantined?
a. Oh, yes.
11.

And you think that was the next day?
a. Yes.

#10 Now, do you remember that two or three days later on July 21st
Reed and Lazear came down? No. PSH
a. I don't remember anything except I know it must have
been two or three days after that Reed was there. He was
in Godfrey's office -- I didn't see Lazear though.

Do you remember anyone else with Reed?
a. No.
(Dr. Hench relating to Mr. Tate the incident of the letter which
indicated that Lazear was there also) Error - Lazear went alone
the week of July 30 as per
his letter of Aug 5
& of Jul 29
to his mother (see my copies of her letters)
(Mr. Tate) I was interested in people coming down because
I would take the telephone messages and then all of them
went to Godfrey's office and I was always in Godfrey's office;
I know Agramonte was in there and I know Reed came, and
Lazear may have, too -- I wouldn't swear -- it's a long
time ago.

Did Reed make rounds with Godfrey?
a. Yes. He went through the whole place.

Did you go along?
a. Yes.

Now, why did you go with them?
a. I went with Godfrey so I could take notes of anything
Godfrey wanted to tell me.

And you made rounds with Reed and Godfrey?
a. Yes.
12.

Was there anyone else with you?
a. I don't remember that there was.

But you wouldn't say there wasn't?
a. I wouldn't say there wasn't -- there's a possibility ....

You went with Reed and Godfrey and took notes or did any little
errands they wanted?
a. Yes.

Do you remember any of the conversation -- do you remember what
Reed said to Godfrey?
a. No. Only one thing I do have a kind of dim remembrance
of -- Agramonte went through every ward and was quite a long
while going around. He inspected every patient and I remember
going around with Reed it was more of a fast walk. He didn't
pay so much attention to everyone of them.

Now, did Dr. Reed go over in the post morten room at all?
a. I don't know.

Do you remember anything more about the visit of Dr. Reed?
a. No, that's all I remember.

As far as you know, he was there only one day?
a. Yes.

You didn't hear of any angry remarks?
a. No.

Did any other clerk make rounds?
a. There were no other clerks.

11. When did you become clerk?
a. I couldn't tell you exactly. I wasn't clerk until the built
the big hospital --- I think I was working in the pharmacy
and Godfrey picked me for his clerk, wanted me to do
13.
some clerical work for him.

Was that in the spring of 1900?
a. I don't remember --- it was shortly after that hospital
was built -- very shortly.

How long were you clerk -- how many months?
a. Well, I was clerk all the way through until I was
transferred -- it was from the time they built that new
hospital, but, of course, I don't know exactly when that
was built.

#11 Now, we're back to question 11. What were the attitudes
of the doctors and the nurses, the soldiers and the Hospital
Corps men when they learned that it was yellow fever?
a. I don't think there was any particular notice taken of it.
I don't think anybody paid much attention -- they just knew it
was yellow fever, and that's all. They had so many diseases
there that they didn't bother whether it was yellow fever or ...
they had smallpox there, and many tropical diseases.

Were there many soldiers that died of yellow fever there?
a. Yes, there were quite a few.

What do you mean by quite a few?
a. I couldn't tell you. It kept us busy getting wooden
coffins -- the dead house was just piled up.

What do you mean, they kept you busy getting coffins?
a. Wooden boxes.

You had to go down where? The quartermasters, and bring them up
to the hospital?
a. I suppose so.
14.

You had to do some of that?
a. No, I didn't have to -- I saw them there. The reason
that's called to my attention, one morning I went down
and passed by the dead house early and there was a doctor
there, he had a long black beard -- I forget his name
(added by Mr. Tate -- his name was Persenol)* and he had
been working all night, and he looked tired out, and he was
sitting there. He said something to me about -- he put his
hands back on those coffins -- and said it was such a shame
that those men had to die. And I got an idea that the
doctor thought that this was yellow fever and if they had
treated them for yellow fever they might not have died.

Now, was there any criticism among the hospital corps, among your-
selves, of Dr. Godfrey or the other doctors there?
a. No. I didn't ever hear any.

The men didn't say, for instance -- “if they had only had some
intelligent doctors” ...
a. No. In the Army at that time, you took everything as
it came. There wasn't any criticism.

Did you every hear any criticism of Dr. Godfrey later?
a. No.

When you went over to Camp Columbia, did you ever hear any
criticism?
a. No, I never heard anything there.

12 #12 This question is regarding the identification of various photographs.
Photo No. 1. Parque Central - Pinar del Rio. No comment.
15.
*This name is spelled differently on a previous page and I do not
know which is correct, so merely call attention to the difference. C.B.
Photo No. 2 - Camp, 1st Inf. Does it mean anything to you? No.
Comment re No. 2: Mr. Tate thinks that on the right is west
and that the tent hospital was across the road behind the
photographer.
Photo No. 3 - This is the hospital where they had the yellow fever
patients?
a. That's the one I don't remember. They evidently moved them
after Reed was down there, but I don't remember.

(Photo No. 3 is the hospital for yellow fever victims and Mr. Tate be-
lieves, or assumes that this was erected after Walter Reed and the
others identified the illness as yellow fever, and they moved them out
of the wooden hospital into the tents.)
You don't remember where this was?
Photo #4 was the old Quartel or garrison. Who lived in here?
a. the 1st Inf......This was occupied by Spanish troops and
they moved out and we finally got it cleaned up and the 1st Inf.
moved in.

When was it occupied by Spanish troops?
a. It was occupied up to shortly before we got there. And
when we reached Havanna, the Spanish troops were still there, you
know. They had moved out of this and gone down to Havanna. So this
wasn't occupied at that time.

When you got there, there were no Spanish troops?
a. That's right, they were all gone.

So in 1897 this was occupied by Spanish troops?
a. Yes.
16.

When did the 1st Inf. move in?
a. Somewhere around the time that the hospital was built.

You didn't live there?
a. No, I never lived there. They wanted to get the troops out
of the field before the winter rains came.

Photo 5 - Quartel, Doherty wagon marked with Red Cross standing in front.
#13 (Mr. Tate) The infantry had Doherty wagons, but not marked with
Red Cross, those were ambulances. There was a wall, but the
windows were boarded up. Three downstairs windows where the
Doherty wagon is, between three arched entrances on the left and two
✓ large doors on the left. These three windows were in the QuartelCarcel. The
one just behind and to the left of the Doherty wagon, with the bars
(otherwise unprotected) was in the sentry room.
(Mr. Tate replying to a question about distance as indicated
in the photo): It was about 20 feet from the outer wall to
the inner or courtyard wall. The two windows behind the wagon
were the two outer windows of the QuartelCarcel. The windows were
boarded up and inside there was a board partition between the
prisoners and the two windows right behind the wagon, to stop
people passing anything in to them such as liquor or knives.
There were Army cots in there. The number of cots varied depend-
ing on the number of prisoners. There was room for 15 to 20
prisoners. They slept here, but during the day, they were worked.
The door to the right of the wagon was the door to a corridor.
(So far as Mr. Tate knows, this door did not lead directly to the
prisoners' room, he always entered through the middle of the
three arched gates.) Upstairs were officers' quarters, offices,
court martial hearing rooms. The first floor was
occupied by some of the infantry ...........
17.

Photo 6
Inner court, view of the quadrangle. Mr. Tate says we are
looking at the back end. He remembers the water tank in the
rear of the quartel.

Photo 7
Behind the quartel and perhaps shows infantry quarters.

Photo 8
Mr. Tate has no recollection of this one -- nothing to do
with yellow fever story.

Photo 9
No recollection.

13 Discussion of the words quartel and carcel (carcel is same as
guard house -- the carcel was in the quartel.
What was the usual cause of imprisonment:
a. Absent without leave, drinking, fighting.

What was the usual length of imprisonment:
a. It all depended on the officer who heard the case.
Summary court martial usually meant 30 days and 30 dollars.
General court martial was much more serious.

14 14) What did you hear about the incident of the prisoner who got sick
with yellow fever?
Mr. Tate replied that he has no recollection about Private
Haskins who died, or Private Schie. Both of these men got
yellow fever while they were in the guardhouse. Haskins died
on the 15th of July, 1900 and Schie survived. Mr. Tate recalls
nothing about these individual cases but report No. 40988
is in his handwriting.
18.

15 15) You told me there were five other men with you at Pinar del Rio who
went with you from there to Camp Columbia. Who were they?
a. Private Williamson,
William Olsen (17)
The numbers refer to those in the photo
p of Gen. Truby's book.
John Morris (15)
Haroldson (26)
(Jernegan not in picture referred to)
Acting Hospital Steward Arnold (9)
(Five, for sure, probably Jernegan)
(The above served with Mr. Tate in the hospital, went to Pinar
del Rio with him and from there to Columbia Barracks.

16 When did you go from Pinar del Rio to Columbia?
a. I arrived Sept 9, 1900 at Columbia Barracks. Went by train.
We left in the morning and arrived that night.

Why did you go there?
a. The reason we were up there in the first place, after the
war there were a lot of bandits in the mountains, on the other
side, and they would come up these mountain trails and attack
the interior and then go back. The Spanish soldiers could
never get them because they couldn't get over those trails and
we couldn't get them either until we sent to the United States
and got mountain batteries and pack trains and pack mules and
went out after them. Then I suppose we wiped all of them out,
and with this yellow fever business there was no use in having
an army there.

Did the whole hospital break up then?
a. Yes, it all broke up.

The whole hospital unit broke up the day you left?
a. I don't know if it was the same day.
19.

17 Where did you live at Camp Columbia?
a. I lived in a barracks. In one of the two hospital barracks
(#102, Truby (51) which was connected to No. 103 by a board
walk with railing and steps from the board walk down to the
ground.

How many in a room?
a. I don't remember. Probably 20.

18 What were your duties at Camp Columbia?
a. I was a hospital clerk.

For whom?
a. For the commanding officer.

When did you leave Columbia Camp?
a. August 11, 1901.

You were clerk for the commanding officer all the time?
a. (I don't have that answer but believe it was ‘yes’)

Who was the commanding officer?
a. I am talking about when I first got there -- Stark had
gone and Pinto was commanding officer, then Lt. Truby taking
Stark's place and then when Stark came back......Wait a
minute, there was somebody after Stark because Stark had
a nervous breakdown and left -- and that was shortly before
I left, there was someone else in charge for a month or so,
I don't know who it was, maybe Major Kean. Major Kean was at
the hospital but what he did I don't remember because he was
chief surgeon of that department; I think, he ran the hospital
for a while.
20.

Can you give me anything about the personality of Jernegan or Olsen,
or any of those people?
a. Olsen was a very placid disposition, good-natured,
competent, and a fine soldier.
Morris was a short, fat man, of a very jolly disposition.
His funny stories of his imaginary adventures were a source
of entertainment to us all. He was always ready for any duty,
and though he did a lot of affected growling, performed all
his duties well.
Harroldson* was a handsome young fellow. Mostly performed
nursing duties, and was pleasant and popular.
Williamson was a quiet young man. Never took part in any
of soldier's vices, such as drinking, gambling, etc. He studied
Spanish under an old Castillian in Pinar del Rio who was a
Yale graduate. He was respected and liked by all.
I don't remember much about De Larue.
It was rumored that Acting Steward Arnold had been a doctor,
but had to give up practice for some reason, and had entered the
Hospital Corps. He was a fine gentleman and one of the best-
liked non-coms.

How often were you at Camp Lazear?
a. I was only there one time.

Why were you there?
a. I used to make sick call at the 7th Cavalry with the
doctor every morning and one morning he said he had to go
down to Camp Lazear.

What doctor?
a. Dr. Amador. On this particular morning he said he had
* I think this is spelled
differently previously in text.
21.
to go to Camp Lazear so we drove down in the ambulance and
stopped at the big oak tree outside the place (Dr. Hench:
“Here's the oak tree,”...to which Mr. Tate replied “yes”.)
He got off and went into one of these tents and he came out
again after about five minutes and got in the wagon and
that was the only time I was there. It was strictly
quarantined.

Do you remember anything about it?
a. No, just a lot of tents. I didn't even get out of the
wagon. I presume he told me -- he was very talktative -- but
I have forgotten. I think he went to see Dr. Ames about
something.

Did you ever have any dealings with the Los Animas Hospital?
a. No.

Did you know anything about the yellow fever hospital across the
railroad track from the post hospital?
a. I saw it.

Did you go there often?
a. No. One time I took a walk a way out around these buildings.
You know there's an argument as to whether there were three huts there,
whether there were six, there, or whether there were four or eight?
a. Yes. I have heard that argument. Of course, Lambert was
there longer than anybody else and Lambert swears it was four.
Let me tell you, there's a map made by the Quartermaster's
Department and that's made by surveyors and I've looked at that
22.
map and I know all of this hospital -- every building in it --
and they were all according to size and shape and distances
apart. Why would those surveyors get all of this exactly
accurate and go over there and put in eight buildings if they
weren't there? I don't believe it -- I think there were eight
buildings there. Lambert was a good fellow and he wouldn't
tell a lie, but was, I think, honestly mistaken. When I got
there, there were no tents, there were little buildings, but
I don't remember how many .... I examined that map with a
magnifying glass...it's an official map and absolutely correct.

Why should these surveyors be so accurate about everything else and
put in some little yellow fever huts that were never there? On the
1902 map there are eight little huts. Mr. Tate says those must have
been there in 1900 and 1901 because there was no reason after 1901 to
build any more.
You remember that little bridge? On the model here, it is here over
the railroad tracks, but Lambert thinks it was over here. The
hospital is over here (Mr. Tate, “yes”) and this is the railroad track
and here is the laundry or something, and the model shows the bridge
in between -- not centered -- but in between. Lambert thinks it was
over here. Do you remember? Where did the bridge cross the railroad
tracks?
a. I'm just trying to remember it. I couldn't say.
Where did the bridge cross the railroad tracks in relation to the

a. I don't know. (I've got an idea, but I wouldn't say it.)
